digest.editor_note: Fellow Humans, the dominant story this morning is not the Nasdaq bounce or Nvidia's earnings — it's Saudi Arabia quietly ramping oil output in anticipation of a US strike on Iran, which tells you everything about where geopolitical risk is actually priced. Markets are choosing to look at the cheerful side of the ledger today, but the Middle East is doing its best to remind everyone that complacency has a cost.

sentiment.label: Cautious
sentiment.context: Equity markets rebounding from AI panic while Saudi Arabia pre-positions for a potential Iran conflict and geopolitical risk premiums quietly build in oil.

stories.headline: Saudi Arabia Pre-Positions Oil Supply for Potential US Strike on Iran
stories.body: Saudi crude shipments surged to 7.3 million barrels per day in the first 24 days of February 2026 — the highest since April 2023 — as Riyadh activates a contingency plan to offset supply disruptions if the US strikes Iran. Trump has publicly floated a 'limited military strike' to force Tehran into a new nuclear deal, while Iran has warned of immediate retaliation and potential closure of the Strait of Hormuz, which handles 20-30% of global seaborne oil. Saudi spare capacity stands at roughly 2.4 million bpd, a buffer that would be tested severely in a full disruption scenario.

stories.headline: Nasdaq Rebounds 250 Points as Markets Shrug Off AI Unemployment Doomsday Report
stories.body: Tech stocks clawed back losses Wednesday after a Citrini Research essay warning of AI-driven unemployment above 10% and a 38% S&P 500 plunge by June 2028 rattled markets earlier in the week, sending the Dow down over 800 points on Monday. White House CEA acting chair Pierre Yared dismissed the paper as 'science fiction' that 'violates basic accounting in economics,' while Citadel Securities argued historical waves of technological change have not rendered labor obsolete. Nvidia reported earnings after the bell, providing the sector's next real test of sentiment.

stories.headline: Cuban Coast Guard Kills Four on US-Flagged Speedboat, Escalating US-Cuba Tensions
stories.body: Cuba's Interior Ministry confirmed its coast guard shot dead four people and wounded six aboard a Florida-registered speedboat one nautical mile from its northern coast, claiming the vessel fired first. Havana subsequently alleged the occupants were armed Cuban-Americans attempting to 'infiltrate the island and unleash terrorism.' Secretary of State Marco Rubio, traveling in the Caribbean, said the US would not rely on Cuba's account and would 'respond accordingly' once facts are established — a geopolitical flashpoint arriving at a moment when the US is already strangling Cuba's fuel supply.

stories.headline: US Greenlights Resale of Venezuelan Oil to Cuba's Private Sector
stories.body: The US Treasury's OFAC announced it would adopt a favorable licensing policy for resale of Venezuelan-origin oil to Cuba, provided transactions benefit the Cuban private sector rather than the government, military, or intelligence services. The partial easing follows a near-total fuel blockade that has left Cuban hospitals cutting services and streets piling up with uncollected rubbish. The carve-out is narrow and the humanitarian situation on the island remains acute, with Canada separately pledging CAD $8 million in aid via the UN.

stories.headline: US Strategic Bitcoin Reserve May Be 30% Smaller Than Advertised Due to Bitfinex Litigation
stories.body: Of the roughly 328,372 BTC the US government controls — worth approximately $21.6 billion — some 94,643 BTC is tied to the 2016 Bitfinex hack and subject to potential court-ordered restitution, which would mechanically shrink the reserve to around 234,000 BTC. Prosecutors have already asked a federal court to approve returning the assets to Bitfinex as in-kind restitution, and Trump's executive order explicitly carves out court-ordered dispositions. The distinction matters: a restitution transfer is not a sovereign sale, but markets counting every government-held coin as permanently strategic are building on contested ground.

stories.headline: Op-Ed: China Deploys AI in Factories While America Debates It in Conference Rooms
stories.body: Former White House economist Jonas Nahm argues in the NYT that the US-China AI gap is a manufacturing execution problem, not just an R&D competition: Tesla's Shanghai factory dramatically outperforms its California counterpart on output per worker, and China has over 30,000 'smart factories' already operational. Xiaomi's Beijing plant produces a car every 76 seconds using 700 robots and AI-driven defect detection, while US manufacturers — especially smaller ones — are stuck with outdated equipment and manual data entry. Nahm's prescription is blunt: Washington must shift focus from trade flows to factory-floor deployment.

stories.headline: BNZ Reverses Mortgage Rate Hike, Cuts 3-Year Fixed Rate Back Below 5%
stories.body: Bank of New Zealand reversed its December rate hike cycle, cutting three, four, and five-year fixed home loan rates by 10-40 basis points effective Wednesday, bringing its three-year rate to 4.99%. The move follows a more dovish-than-expected Reserve Bank of New Zealand OCR decision, which signaled a later and shallower tightening path than markets had priced, causing wholesale rates to ease. Westpac made comparable cuts last week; the back-and-forth on longer-term mortgage pricing reflects ongoing market uncertainty about the terminal rate path.

quote.text: The market can remain irrational longer than you can remain solvent.
quote.attribution: John Maynard Keynes, A Tract on Monetary Reform, 1923
quote.editor_note: Fellow Humans, prediction markets are busy establishing their first case law this morning, with Kalshi fining an MrBeast editor for insider-trading YouTube outcomes while a separate $100,000 bet on a government alien disclosure sits unresolved and faintly terrifying. Meanwhile, the actual geopolitical news — Ukraine peace sequencing, Modi at the Knesset, cartels designated terrorists after El Mencho's death — is moving fast enough that the aliens story almost makes sense by comparison.

sentiment.label: Cautious
sentiment.context: Geopolitical uncertainty across Ukraine, the Middle East, and US-Mexico cartel dynamics keeps markets in a watchful holding pattern, with no decisive risk catalyst in either direction.

stories.headline: Zelenskiy and Trump agree Ukraine talks should escalate to leaders' summit in March
stories.body: Following a phone call that included Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner, Zelenskiy confirmed that trilateral US-Ukraine-Russia talks are set for early March, with the explicit goal of advancing to a presidential-level meeting. Ukraine is simultaneously negotiating a 'prosperity package' covering reconstruction financing, with Kyiv targeting $800 billion in public and private funds over a decade. The territorial question remains the core impasse, with Moscow and Kyiv still far apart.

stories.headline: Rep. Chip Roy pushes bill to permanently codify cartel terrorist designations after El Mencho killing
stories.body: Following a US-led operation that killed Jalisco New Generation Cartel leader El Mencho, Rep. Chip Roy is pressing House colleagues to pass the Drug Cartel Terrorist Designation Act, which would enshrine Trump's executive order into statute. Violence in Puerto Vallarta has killed over 70 people since the operation, and the US Embassy has issued shelter-in-place guidance for Americans in parts of Mexico. Roy's argument: executive orders can be reversed by the next administration; legislation cannot.

stories.headline: Larry Summers to resign from Harvard as Epstein document review continues
stories.body: Former Treasury Secretary Larry Summers will retire from Harvard at the end of the academic year, remaining on leave until then, after his name appeared hundreds of times in Justice Department Epstein file releases. Emails revealed Summers consulting Epstein on a personal relationship and using a racial slur in a separate exchange; Summers had previously called his association with Epstein 'a major error in judgement.' The resignation follows Nobel laureate Richard Axel's departure from Columbia, signaling that the Epstein document releases are still extracting institutional casualties.

stories.headline: Kalshi fines MrBeast editor for insider trading, opens enforcement precedent for prediction markets
stories.body: Kalshi suspended editor Artem Kaptur for two years and fined him approximately $20,000 after he netted around $5,000 betting on MrBeast video outcomes using non-public information obtained through his job. In a separate action, former California gubernatorial candidate Kyle Langford received a five-year ban for betting $200 on his own candidacy. Kalshi has reported both cases to the CFTC and disclosed it has opened 200 insider trading investigations over the past year — a number that underscores how rapidly enforcement is scaling alongside the industry.

stories.headline: Nearly $200,000 bet on US alien disclosure triggers insider trading speculation on Kalshi
stories.body: A single trader placed two bets totalling close to $200,000 on Kalshi Monday night, wagering that the Trump administration will confirm alien life or technology exists by end of December — briefly pushing implied odds above one-in-three. The trades arrived days after any public alien-related news had subsided, with no congressional hearings or credible leaks circulating online at the time. Kalshi's own enforcement team is actively investigating insider trading across its platform, making this particular wager an uncomfortable data point.

stories.headline: Modi addresses Knesset, declares India stands with Israel 'with full conviction'
stories.body: In the first address by an Indian leader to Israel's parliament, Prime Minister Modi received a standing ovation and affirmed that India 'stands with Israel firmly' while condemning the October 7 attacks as 'barbaric.' The visit deepens a defence-heavy bilateral relationship: India spent $20.5 billion on Israeli weapons between 2020 and 2024, and the two countries signed a bilateral investment treaty in September 2025. Modi's alignment carries weight given that Indian public opinion has grown increasingly critical of Israel's Gaza campaign, which has killed at least 72,000 people.

stories.headline: Tinubu extends Nigeria's raw shea nut export ban by one year through February 2027
stories.body: President Tinubu approved a one-year extension of the ban on raw shea nut exports, channelling supply through the Nigerian Commodity Exchange framework and withdrawing all existing waivers. The policy rationale is value-addition arbitrage: processed shea butter fetches 10 to 20 times the price of raw nuts in international markets. The Federal Ministry of Finance has been directed to open a dedicated NESS Support Window to finance domestic processing capacity.
